question: Which structural layer in some cell types is composed mainly of carbohydrates like cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin in the ratio 4:3:3 and some fatty substances like wax?
solution:
• The cell wall is a rigid outer layer found in plant cells, fungi, and some prokaryotes.
  • It primarily consists of carbohydrates such as cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, usually in the ratio 4:3:3.
  • These components provide mechanical strength, structural support, and resistance to microbial attack.
  • Waxy or fatty substances, such as cutin or suberin, may also be present, offering waterproofing and protection.
  • It is absent in animal cells, which only possess a plasma membrane.

Additional Information:

  • Primary cell wall is flexible and found in growing cells.
  • Secondary cell wall is thicker, lignin-rich, and offers rigidity.
  • Plasmodesmata in the cell wall allow intercellular communication in plants.

question: The Primary function of which channel protein is to transport water across the cell membrane in response to the osmotic gradient created by active solute transport?
solution:
• Aquaporins are specialized channel proteins embedded in the cell membrane.
  • Their primary function is to facilitate the rapid transport of water molecules across the membrane.
  • This movement occurs in response to osmotic gradients created by the active transport of solutes like ions or sugars.
  • Aquaporins are selective for water and do not permit the passage of ions or other solutes.
  • They are especially important in kidney cells, plant roots, and red blood cells where water balance is crucial.

Additional Information:

  • Aquaporins were first discovered in 1992 and earned Peter Agre the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2003.
  • Aquaporin-2 is regulated by vasopressin in human kidneys to control water reabsorption.
  • Mucins are glycoproteins involved in mucus production; Transferrin transports iron; Cupredoxins are copper-containing electron transport proteins.

question: Most centrioles have a ________ structure of triple microtubules, which are present in pairs and arranged orthogonally after duplication.
solution:
• Centrioles are cylindrical cell structures found mainly in animal cells and help in cell division.
  • Each centriole is composed of nine triplet microtubules, forming a 9 + 0 arrangement — i.e., 9 sets of triplet microtubules arranged in a circle with no central pair.
  • After duplication, centrioles exist in orthogonal pairs (right angles to each other), helping form the centrosome, the microtubule-organizing center.
  • This 9 + 0 structure is a key identifier, distinguishing centrioles from cilia and flagella, which have a 9 + 2 structure.

Additional Information:

  • Centrioles are absent in most plant cells and fungi.
  • The basal bodies of cilia and flagella also have the 9 + 0 microtubule pattern.
  • Centrioles play a vital role in organizing the spindle fibers during mitosis and meiosis.

question: Which is a reversible, fluorescent red, acidic dye used to stain cytoplasm, red blood cells, collagen and muscle fibres for historical examination?
solution:
• Eosin is a red, fluorescent, acidic dye widely used in histology (tissue studies).
  • It is reversible and specifically stains basic (alkaline) cellular components.
  • Eosin stains the cytoplasm, red blood cells (RBCs), collagen, and muscle fibers in shades of pink to red.
  • It is typically used in combination with hematoxylin (which stains nuclei blue-purple) in H&E staining, the most common staining technique in pathology.

Additional Information:

  • Safranin is a basic dye used to stain nuclei red in plants or bacterial cells.
  • Crystal violet is used in Gram staining to identify Gram-positive bacteria.
  • Alizarin is used for staining calcium deposits in tissues or bones.

question: Which cellular structure controls cell motility, adhesion, and polarity at interphase, and facilitates the organisation of spindle poles during mitosis?
solution:
• Centrosomes are the main microtubule-organizing centers (MTOCs) of animal cells.
  • During interphase, centrosomes regulate cell motility, adhesion, and polarity by organizing the cytoskeleton.
  • In mitosis, they facilitate the formation and organization of spindle poles, which are essential for accurate chromosome segregation.
  • Each centrosome typically contains two centrioles arranged orthogonally and surrounded by pericentriolar material (PCM).

Additional Information:

  • Peroxisomes are involved in fatty acid oxidation and detoxification.
  • Lysosomes contain digestive enzymes for breaking down cellular waste.
  • Glyoxysomes are specialized peroxisomes in plants that convert fats into sugars during germination.

question: What is the percentage of proteins in the cell membrane?
solution:
• The cell membrane (also called the plasma membrane) is composed of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates.
  • Proteins in the membrane are classified as integral (embedded) and peripheral (surface-bound) proteins.
  • The percentage of proteins in the plasma membrane typically ranges between 40–60% by weight, depending on the cell type and function.
  • These proteins are responsible for transport, signal transduction, structural support, and enzymatic activity.

Additional Information:

  • The lipid component usually contributes 30–50%, mainly phospholipids and cholesterol.
  • Carbohydrates, though present in smaller amounts, are important for cell recognition and adhesion.
  • The membrane is described by the Fluid Mosaic Model, proposed by Singer and Nicolson in 1972.

question: What do you call the fluid matrix filling in the cell?
solution:
• The cytoplasm is the fluid matrix that fills the interior of all cells between the plasma membrane and the nucleus.
  • It consists of cytosol (the fluid part), organelles, and various inclusions.
  • The cytoplasm provides a medium for chemical reactions, supports cell structure, and enables transport of materials within the cell.
  • It plays a crucial role in cell expansion, growth, and replication.

Additional Information:

  • Golgi bodies are involved in packaging and transporting proteins.
  • Ribosomes are the sites of protein synthesis, either floating in cytoplasm or bound to ER.
  • Plasmids are small circular DNA molecules found mainly in bacteria, not part of the cytoplasm itself.

question: The main function of centriole is:
option_1: To maintain mineral composition in bacterial cell
option_2: To help plant cell for multiplication
option_3: To help cell division in animal cell
option_4: To maintain rigidity in plant cell
solution:
• The centriole is a cylindrical organelle found mainly in animal cells and certain lower plant cells.
  • Its main function is to assist in cell division, especially mitosis and meiosis, by helping form the spindle fibers that segregate chromosomes.
  • During the cell cycle, a pair of centrioles duplicates and moves to opposite poles of the cell to organize the mitotic spindle.
  • Centrioles are part of the centrosome, the primary microtubule-organizing center (MTOC) of animal cells.

Additional Information:

  • Centrioles have a 9 + 0 arrangement of microtubule triplets.
  • They are absent in higher plant cells, which use other structures for organizing microtubules.
  • Centrioles also play a role in forming cilia and flagella (basal bodies).

question: During which phase of the cell cycle does metabolic changes assemble the cytoplasmic material required for mitosis and cytokinesis?
solution:
• The question asks "during which phase do metabolic changes assemble the cytoplasmic material required for mitosis and cytokinesis", not when division occurs.
  • These preparatory metabolic changes, including synthesis of proteins, enzymes, and other cytoplasmic materials, take place during the G2 phase, just before mitosis.
  • The M phase is where mitosis and cytokinesis actually happen, but assembly of materials occurs in G2, making option (a) the biologically correct choice.
  • Therefore, the marked answer (c) is incorrect based on cell biology principles.

Correct Answer: (a) G2 phase

Additional Information:

  • G1 phase: Cell growth and routine metabolism
  • S phase: DNA replication
  • G2 phase: Final preparation—synthesis of cytoplasmic elements needed for M phase
  • M phase: Actual cell division into daughter cells

question: How long are red blood cells in diameter?
solution:
• Red Blood Cells (RBCs), also called erythrocytes, are biconcave disc-shaped cells responsible for transporting oxygen.
  • The diameter of a typical human RBC is approximately 5 micrometers (μm).
  • This small size allows RBCs to easily pass through capillaries, which can be as narrow as 5–10 μm.
  • Their thin central region (~2 μm) helps in gas exchange efficiency.

Additional Information:

  • RBCs lack a nucleus in mammals, enabling more space for hemoglobin.
  • The average thickness of RBCs is about 2.0 μm at the edge and less in the center.
  • An adult human has around 5 million RBCs per microliter of blood.

question:
Which cell organelle appears as rounded or sausage-shaped structures under electron microscopy, measuring about 0.5 – 1.0m in diameter and 2-8m in length?
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749538866864_image001.png
solution:
• Mitochondria are known as the "powerhouses of the cell" because they produce ATP through cellular respiration.
  • Under electron microscopy, they appear as rounded or sausage-shaped structures.
  • Their typical size is about 5–1.0 μm in diameter and 2–8 μm in length, depending on the cell type and activity.
  • Each mitochondrion has a double membrane — the inner membrane is folded into cristae to increase surface area for energy production.

Additional Information:

  • Mitochondria contain their own DNA and ribosomes, enabling them to synthesize some of their own proteins.
  • They are abundant in cells with high energy demands, such as muscle and nerve cells.
  • Lysosomes are smaller, single-membrane vesicles containing digestive enzymes.
  • Plastids are found only in plant cells (e.g., chloroplasts) and are generally larger.
  • Ribosomes are tiny (~20 nm) and are not membrane-bound.

question: What is the length of a bacterial cell?
solution:
• The average length of a bacterial cell typically ranges from 3 to 5 micrometers (μm), depending on the species.
  • Most bacteria are unicellular prokaryotic organisms and come in various shapes such as coccus (spherical), bacillus (rod-shaped), and spirillum (spiral).
  • The diameter of bacteria generally ranges from 2 to 2.0 μm, while the length varies between 1 to 10 μm, with 3–5 μm being the most common for rod-shaped bacteria (bacilli).

Additional Information:

  • Some bacteria like Mycoplasma are as small as 0.1 μm, while others like Epulopiscium can reach lengths of over 500 μm, though such cases are rare.
  • Bacteria reproduce mainly through binary fission.
  • The size and shape of a bacterium influence its surface area to volume ratio, affecting nutrient uptake and metabolic rate.

question: What do you call a Glycocalyx that is a loose sheath type?
solution:
• Glycocalyx is a polysaccharide-rich outer coating found in many bacterial cells.
  • It helps in protection, adhesion, and immune evasion.
  • When the glycocalyx is loosely arranged and easily removable, it is called a slime layer.
  • In contrast, when it is well-organized, thick, and tightly bound, it is called a capsule.

Additional Information:

  • Slime layer provides protection from dehydration and helps in surface attachment.
  • Capsules increase virulence by protecting bacteria from phagocytosis.
  • Mesosomes are folded invaginations of the plasma membrane, involved in respiration or DNA replication.
  • Tubules are unrelated structures not associated with glycocalyx.

question: Which process is sometimes called “Reduction division” because it reduces the number of chromosomes to half the normal number to form sperm and eggs?
solution:
• Meiosis is a type of cell division that results in the formation of gametes (sperm and eggs) with half the chromosome number of the parent cell.
  • It is often called “reduction division” because it reduces the diploid (2n) chromosome number to haploid (n).
  • This ensures that when fertilization occurs, the resulting zygote has the correct diploid number.
  • Meiosis consists of two successive divisions — Meiosis I (reductional division) and Meiosis II (equational division).

Additional Information:

  • Amitosis is direct cell division without spindle formation, seen in prokaryotes and some eukaryotic cells.
  • Cytokinesis is the division of the cytoplasm following nuclear division.
  • Karyokinesis refers to the division of the cell's nucleus.

question: Which is the primary structural component responsible for most of the mechanical strength of the cell wall?
solution:
• The primary structural component that provides mechanical strength to the plant cell wall is cellulose.
  • Cellulose is a polysaccharide made up of β-1,4 linked glucose units, forming long, rigid, unbranched chains.
  • These chains bundle together into microfibrils, which are extremely strong and give the cell wall its rigidity and tensile strength.
  • This structure allows plant cells to maintain shape, resist turgor pressure, and stand upright without skeletal systems.

Additional Information:

  • Heparin is an anticoagulant (blood thinner), not found in cell walls.
  • Glycogen is an energy storage polysaccharide in animals, not structural.
  • Chitin is the main structural component in fungal cell walls and arthropod exoskeletons, not plants.

question: By what name are the flat membrane-enclosed sacs present in the Golgi apparatus known?
solution:
• The Golgi apparatus is a membrane-bound organelle involved in modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids.
  • It is composed of a series of flattened, membrane-enclosed sacs called cisternae.
  • These cisternae are arranged in stacks and have a cis face (receiving side) and a trans face (shipping side).
  • Each cisterna contains specific enzymes to perform sequential biochemical modifications.

Additional Information:

  • Lamellae are thin layers or plates found in chloroplasts or bone.
  • Cristae are the folded inner membrane structures of mitochondria.
  • Stroma is the fluid-filled matrix inside chloroplasts.

question: Which cell found in the bone marrow acts as a repair system for the body?
solution:
• Stem cells found in the bone marrow serve as a repair system for the body.
  • These are undifferentiated cells capable of dividing and differentiating into various specialized cell types like blood cells, bone cells, and immune cells.
  • Bone marrow stem cells are especially important in regenerating damaged tissues, producing red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets regularly.
  • There are two main types: Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) (form blood cells) and Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) (form bone, cartilage, and fat cells).

Additional Information:

  • Bone cells are mature cells (like osteocytes) involved in bone maintenance, not regeneration of multiple cell types.
  • Fat cells (adipocytes) store energy and help in insulation.
  • Muscle cells are specialized for contraction and movement, not regeneration of diverse tissues.

question: During cell division, the formation of a new cell wall is followed by the accumulation of:
solution:
• During plant cell division, particularly in cytokinesis, a cell plate forms between the two daughter nuclei to develop into a new cell wall.
  • This process is guided by a structure called the phragmoplast, which is made of microtubules, actin filaments, and remnants of the mitotic spindle.
  • The phragmoplast facilitates the transport and assembly of vesicles from the Golgi apparatus, which carry materials to build the new cell wall.
  • Thus, accumulation of vesicles and cell wall materials occurs along the phragmoplast, making it essential for cell wall formation post-division.

Additional Information:

  • Peristome refers to structures in moss capsules, unrelated to cell division.
  • Periplasm is the space between inner and outer membranes in Gram-negative bacteria.
  • Protoplast is the cell content minus the cell wall; it does not accumulate after wall formation.

question: Which part of a cell converts nutrients into energy?
solution:
• The mitochondria are known as the "powerhouse of the cell" because they convert nutrients into energy in the form of ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate).
  • This conversion occurs via cellular respiration, primarily in the inner membrane (cristae) of mitochondria.
  • The process includes steps like the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain, which efficiently extract energy from glucose and other molecules.
  • Mitochondria are present in both animal and plant cells, especially in those with high energy demands like muscle and nerve cells.

Additional Information:

  • Cell membrane controls the entry and exit of substances but does not produce energy.
  • Lysosomes are involved in digestion and waste breakdown within the cell.
  • Chromosomes carry genetic information, not involved in energy production.

question: Which cell analysis technique is used to rapidly analyse single cells or particles as they flow through single or multiple lesers while suspended in a buffered salt-based solution?
solution:
• Flow cytometry is a powerful cell analysis technique used to rapidly analyze single cells or particles.
  • In this technique, cells are suspended in a buffered salt-based solution and passed one at a time through a laser beam.
  • As each cell passes the laser(s), detectors measure light scattering and fluorescence, enabling detailed analysis of cell size, granularity, and protein expression.
  • It is widely used in immunology, cancer diagnostics, stem cell research, and cell sorting.

Additional Information:

  • Mass spectroscopy analyzes molecular mass and structure, not live cells in fluid.
  • Electrochemical analysis measures electric signals in chemical reactions, not used for cell flow analysis.
  • Multiple displacement amplification is a DNA amplification technique, not a cell analysis method.

question: The division of cytoplasm is known as:
solution:
• The process in which the cytoplasm divides to form two daughter cells after the nucleus has divided is called cytokinesis.
  • It typically follows karyokinesis (nuclear division) and ensures that each daughter cell gets its own share of cytoplasm and organelles.
  • In animal cells, cytokinesis occurs via cleavage furrow formation, while in plant cells, it occurs through the formation of a cell plate.

Additional Information:

  • Karyokinesis is the division of the nucleus, not the cytoplasm.
  • Cytoskeleton refers to the network of protein filaments providing cell structure and movement.
  • Cytosol is the fluid portion of the cytoplasm, not a process.

question: Which of the following cell organelles can make copies of themselves?
solution:
• Mitochondria are unique cell organelles that possess their own DNA, ribosomes, and machinery for protein synthesis.
  • Because of this, mitochondria can replicate independently of the cell using a process similar to binary fission.
  • This ability supports the endosymbiotic theory, which suggests that mitochondria were once free-living bacteria engulfed by ancestral eukaryotic cells.
  • Their self-replicating property is essential for energy demands, especially in active cells like muscles and neurons.

Additional Information:

  • Golgi apparatus processes and packages proteins but does not replicate on its own.
  • Vacuoles are storage organelles that grow or shrink but do not self-replicate.
  • Cytoplasm is the fluid content of the cell, not an organelle and not capable of self-duplication.

question:
Which type of haploid unicellular eukaryote cells has a diameter of 10m, and about half of their volume is occupied by cup-shaped chloroplasts?
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749538866864_image002.png
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749538866864_image003.png
solution:
• Chlamydomonas is a haploid unicellular eukaryotic alga that belongs to the green algae group (Chlorophyta).
  • It is typically ~10 μm in diameter, making it a microscopic, free-living, motile organism found in freshwater.
  • A distinct feature of Chlamydomonas is the presence of a large, cup-shaped chloroplast that occupies nearly half the cell’s volume.
  • The chloroplast contains pyrenoids for starch synthesis and helps in photosynthesis.

Additional Information:

  • Hydrodictyon is a colonial green alga, not unicellular.
  • Ulva is a multicellular seaweed (also known as sea lettuce).
  • Oedogonium is filamentous and multicellular, not unicellular or cup-shaped.

question: Which cell organelles are known as cell’s post office?
solution:
• The Golgi apparatus is commonly referred to as the “post office” of the cell.
  • It is responsible for modifying, sorting, packaging, and transporting proteins and lipids received from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
  • These substances are packed into vesicles and then sent to their correct destinations inside or outside the cell.
  • The Golgi body plays a key role in secretion, especially in glandular cells and cells involved in transport.

Additional Information:

  • Nucleus is the control center of the cell, housing genetic material (DNA).
  • Ribosomes are the site of protein synthesis, not processing or packaging.
  • Plastids (e.g., chloroplasts) are involved in photosynthesis and storage, not transport or sorting.

question: Which of the following cells are found in the liver of mammals?
solution:
• Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages found in the liver of mammals.
  • They are located in the lumen of liver sinusoids, attached to the walls of the blood vessels.
  • Their primary function is to phagocytose (engulf and digest) pathogens, dead cells, and cellular debris from the blood.
  • Kupffer cells play a vital role in detoxification, immune defense, and recycling of old red blood cells.

Additional Information:

  • Purkinje cells are large neurons found in the cerebellum of the brain.
  • Microglial cells are immune cells of the central nervous system.
  • Sensory cells are part of the sensory organs like eyes, ears, and skin, not the liver.

question: Which of the following cell organelles is made up of ribosomal RNA and protein?
solution:
• Ribosomes are the cell organelles responsible for protein synthesis.
  • They are composed of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and proteins, forming two subunits — large and small.
  • These subunits are assembled in the nucleolus and function in the cytoplasm or attached to the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER).
  • Ribosomes are non-membrane bound and found in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.

Additional Information:

  • Nucleus contains DNA and is the control center of the cell.
  • Golgi body modifies and packages proteins but is made of membranes.
  • Lysosomes are membrane-bound vesicles containing digestive enzymes.

question: In cells, proteins are synthesized in _______ .
solution:
• Proteins are synthesized in the ribosomes, which are often referred to as the “protein factories” of the cell.
  • Ribosomes read the genetic code from messenger RNA (mRNA) and assemble amino acids into polypeptide chains.
  • They can be found freely floating in the cytoplasm or attached to the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER).
  • Ribosomes are composed of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and proteins, and they exist in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.

Additional Information:

  • Mitochondria produce ATP (energy), not proteins.
  • Golgi body modifies, packages, and transports proteins but does not synthesize them.
  • Nucleus stores genetic material but protein synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm or on RER-bound ribosomes.

question: Mitochondria is not found in _______ .
solution:
• Mitochondria are membrane-bound organelles responsible for aerobic respiration and ATP production.
  • They are present in almost all eukaryotic cells, including yeast, algae, fungi, plants, and animals.
  • Bacteria, however, are prokaryotic organisms and lack membrane-bound organelles, including mitochondria.
  • In bacteria, energy production occurs across the plasma membrane via respiratory enzymes embedded in the cell membrane.

Additional Information:

  • Yeast (unicellular fungi), algae, and fungi are all eukaryotic and have mitochondria.
  • The absence of mitochondria is a key feature distinguishing prokaryotes (like bacteria) from eukaryotes.

question: In a plant, _______ is present in the middle lamella, primary cell and secondary walls and accumulates in the initial stages of development during cell expansion.
solution:
• Pectin is a complex polysaccharide found abundantly in the plant cell wall, especially in the middle lamella, and to a lesser extent in the primary and secondary walls.
  • It plays a vital role in cell adhesion, giving structure to plant tissues by binding cells together.
  • During the early stages of cell expansion and development, pectin accumulates and maintains cell wall plasticity.
  • It also helps in water retention and signaling during plant growth.

Additional Information:

  • Chitin is found in fungal cell walls and arthropod exoskeletons, not in plants.
  • Gelatin is an animal protein derived from collagen, absent in plants.
  • Alginate is found in brown algae cell walls, not in higher plants.

question: Select the correct statement.
option_1: Mitochondria and nucleus are found in bacteria
option_2: Ribosomes, mitochondria and lysosomes are found in animal cells
option_3: Chloroplast, ribosomes and nucleus are present in fungal cells
option_4: Mitochondria and nucleus are absent in plant cells
solution:
• The correct statement is (b): Ribosomes, mitochondria, and lysosomes are found in animal cells.
  • Animal cells, being eukaryotic, contain membrane-bound organelles including:
    • Ribosomes – for protein synthesis (found freely and on RER)
    • Mitochondria – for energy production (ATP)
    • Lysosomes – for intracellular digestion and waste removal

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Mitochondria and nucleus are found in bacteria – ❌ Incorrect: Bacteria are prokaryotes; they lack nucleus and mitochondria.
  • (c) Chloroplast, ribosomes and nucleus are present in fungal cells – ❌ Incorrect: Fungi do not have chloroplasts; they are heterotrophic.
  • (d) Mitochondria and nucleus are absent in plant cells – ❌ Incorrect: Plant cells are eukaryotic and do contain both nucleus and mitochondria.

Additional Information:

  • Lysosomes are more prominent in animal cells than in plant cells.
  • Ribosomes are non-membranous organelles found in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
  • Chloroplasts are found in green plant cells and some algae, not in fungi.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding cell membrane?

I. The membrane is selectively permeable to some molecules present on either side of it.

II. Water may also move across this membrane from lower to higher concentration.
option_3: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
• Statement I is correct:

    The cell membrane is selectively permeable, meaning it allows certain molecules (like water, gases, and small solutes) to pass through while restricting others. This selective permeability is essential for maintaining homeostasis within the cell.

  • Statement II is incorrect:

    Water moves across the membrane through osmosis, and osmosis always occurs from a region of higher water concentration to a region of lower water concentration (i.e., from dilute to concentrated solution), not the other way around. Therefore, the statement saying water moves from lower to higher concentration is scientifically incorrect.

Correct Answer: (b) Only I

Additional Information:

  • The cell membrane is made up of a phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins, which help regulate transport.
  • Aquaporins are special protein channels that facilitate water movement across the membrane.
  • This selective nature is critical for nutrient uptake, waste removal, and signal reception.

question: Which form of leucoplast specializes in oil synthesis and storage and is mainly found in the layer of cells in pollen grains that develop pollen grain?
solution:
• Elaioplasts are a specialized type of leucoplast that focus on synthesis and storage of oils and lipids.
  • They are non-pigmented plastids, primarily found in pollen grains, especially in the tapetum layer — a nutritive tissue that supports pollen development.
  • Elaioplasts help store energy-rich compounds essential for the development and viability of pollen.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Gerontoplasts are aged chloroplasts involved in the senescence (aging) process of leaves.
  • Proteinoplasts store and modify proteins; they are found in seeds and other protein-storing tissues.
  • Chloroplasts are green plastids involved in photosynthesis, not oil storage.

question: Which cells, also called neurilemma cells, are the main glial cells in the PNS and play and essential role in the survival and functions of neurons?
solution:
• Schwann cells, also known as neurilemma cells, are the main glial cells of the Peripheral Nervous System (PNS).
  • They play a vital role in supporting neurons, particularly by forming the myelin sheath around axon fibers, which helps in faster nerve impulse conduction.
  • Schwann cells also assist in axon regeneration and repair after injury, making them essential for neuron survival and function in the PNS.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Bipolar cells are neurons found in the retina, not glial cells.
  • Ganglion cells are also retinal neurons involved in visual processing.
  • Photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) detect light in the retina; they are sensory, not glial cells.

question: Which of the following is found in plant cells only?
solution:
• The cell wall is a rigid, protective outer layer found only in plant cells, fungi, algae, and some bacteria.
  • In plant cells, it is primarily composed of cellulose, which gives the cell mechanical strength and structural support.
  • It lies outside the cell membrane and also helps maintain turgor pressure, preventing excessive water intake or loss.
  • The cell wall is absent in animal cells, which is a major distinguishing feature.

Additional Information:

  • Cell membrane (also called plasma membrane) is present in all cell types, including plants, animals, fungi, and bacteria.
  • Nucleolus is found inside the nucleus of both plant and animal cells and plays a key role in ribosome production.
  • Mitochondria are present in both plant and animal cells and are involved in ATP (energy) production via cellular respiration.

question: Which cell organelle containing millions of membrane-bound ribosomes is involved in the production, folding, quality control and dispatch of certain proteins?
solution:
• The Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum (RER) is a membrane-bound cell organelle studded with millions of ribosomes, giving it a "rough" appearance under a microscope.
  • It is primarily involved in the synthesis, folding, quality control, and transport of proteins, especially those that are secreted or inserted into the cell membrane.
  • These ribosomes synthesize polypeptides, which are then folded and modified within the lumen of the RER before being dispatched to the Golgi apparatus for further processing.

Additional Information:

  • Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and detoxification, not protein synthesis.
  • Mitochondria are responsible for ATP production and cellular respiration, not large-scale protein processing.
  • Golgi apparatus modifies, packages, and ships proteins but does not synthesize them; it receives proteins from the RER.

question: The cells having well-organized nuclei with a nuclear membrane are designated as ________ .
solution:
• Cells that have a well-organized nucleus enclosed within a nuclear membrane are known as eukaryotic cells.
  • The term "eukaryote" comes from Greek: "eu" meaning true and "karyon" meaning nucleus.
  • Eukaryotic cells contain membrane-bound organelles such as the nucleus, mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi apparatus.
  • These cells are found in animals, plants, fungi, and protists.

Additional Information:

  • Cheek cells are an example of eukaryotic cells, as they have a distinct nucleus.
  • Prokaryotic cells (like bacteria) do not have a membrane-bound nucleus.
  • Autokaryotic cells is not a standard biological term and is not used to classify cell types.

question: Which component of the cell contains the hereditary material of the cell, the DNA?
solution:
• The nucleus is the control center of the cell and houses the hereditary material, which is DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid).
  • DNA is organized into chromosomes, which contain the genes that determine the cell’s structure, function, and behavior.
  • The nucleus is surrounded by a nuclear membrane and contains nucleoplasm, where chromatin (DNA + proteins) is suspended.
  • It also plays a crucial role in cell division and gene expression regulation.

Additional Information:

  • Cell wall is a rigid protective layer found in plant cells, but it does not contain DNA.
  • Cell membrane controls the movement of substances in and out of the cell but has no genetic material.
  • Cytoplasm is the fluid that fills the cell and holds organelles but does not store DNA (except in prokaryotes, where DNA floats in the cytoplasm due to lack of nucleus).

question: Cells were first observed in cork by _______ in 1665.
solution:
• Robert Hooke, an English scientist, was the first person to observe cells in 1665.
  • He examined thin slices of cork (a plant tissue) under a compound microscope and noticed small box-like structures.
  • He called these structures “cells” because they reminded him of the tiny rooms (cellula) in a monastery.
  • However, what he actually saw were the cell walls of dead plant cells, not living cells.

Additional Information:

  • Anton van Leeuwenhoek was the first to observe living cells (like bacteria and protozoa) using a simple microscope.
  • Theophrastus was an ancient Greek philosopher known as the father of botany, not cell biology.
  • Edward Jenner developed the smallpox vaccine, unrelated to cell discovery.

question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three main parts of the cell?
solution:
• The three main parts of a typical cell are:
    1. Cell membrane – the outer boundary that regulates what enters and exits the cell.
    2. Cytoplasm – the fluid-filled space that holds all organelles except the nucleus.
    3. Nucleus – the control center containing DNA and directing cell activities.
  • While vacuoles are important organelles (especially large in plant cells for storage), they are not considered one of the core structural components of all cells.
  • Hence, vacuole is NOT one of the three fundamental parts of a cell.

Additional Information:

  • Plant cells have a large central vacuole, but in animal cells, vacuoles are small or sometimes absent.
  • The basic structure (nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane) is common to most eukaryotic cells.

question: What is the jelly-like substance between the nucleus and the cell membrane called?
solution:
• The jelly-like substance found between the nucleus and the cell membrane is called the cytoplasm.
  • It is a semi-fluid matrix that contains water, salts, enzymes, and organelles.
  • The cytoplasm provides a medium for biochemical reactions and allows the movement and positioning of organelles within the cell.
  • It includes a fluid portion called cytosol, along with all the internal cell structures (excluding the nucleus).

Additional Information:

  • Plasma refers to the fluid portion of blood, not a cell component.
  • Cell wall is a rigid layer found in plant cells, outside the plasma membrane.
  • Plasma membrane (cell membrane) surrounds the entire cell and controls entry/exit of substances, but is not the internal jelly-like medium.

question: Which component of the cell organelles principally performs the function of packaging materials, to be delivered either to the intra-cellular targets or secreted outside the cell?
solution:
• The Golgi apparatus (also known as the Golgi body or Golgi complex) is the primary organelle responsible for packaging and sorting materials in the cell.
  • It modifies, sorts, and packages proteins and lipids that are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
  • These materials are then packaged into vesicles, which are either sent to intracellular organelles or secreted outside the cell through exocytosis.
  • It is especially active in secretory cells like those in glands.

Additional Information:

  • Chloroplasts are responsible for photosynthesis in plant cells.
  • Mitochondria generate ATP (energy) through cellular respiration.
  • Chromosomes carry genetic information (DNA) and are found in the nucleus, not involved in packaging or secretion.

question: What is the major function of a cell wall?
option_1: It works as a storage for material
option_2: It provides shape and rigidity to the cell
option_3: It is responsible for cell division
option_4: It helps in synthesis of carbohydrate
solution:
• The primary function of the cell wall is to provide shape, strength, and rigidity to the cell.
  • It is a tough, outermost layer found in plant cells, fungi, algae, and some bacteria, but absent in animal cells.
  • In plants, it is mainly composed of cellulose, which offers mechanical support and helps the cell withstand turgor pressure.
  • This rigid structure also protects the cell from mechanical stress and pathogen attack.

Additional Information:

  • (a) Storage is a function of organelles like vacuoles, not the cell wall.
  • (c) Cell division is regulated by the nucleus and centrioles (in animal cells), not the cell wall.
  • (d) Carbohydrate synthesis occurs in chloroplasts and cytoplasm, not in the cell wall.

Correct Answer: (b) It provides shape and rigidity to the cell

question: The cells having nuclear material without a nuclear membrane are termed as ________ .
solution:
• Prokaryotic cells lack a true nucleus; their genetic material (DNA) floats freely in the cytoplasm within a region called the nucleoid.
  • These cells do not contain membrane-bound organelles like mitochondria, ER, or Golgi apparatus.
  • Cell division in prokaryotes occurs by binary fission, a simple and rapid process.

Additional Information:

  • Prokaryotic cells are found in organisms like bacteria and archaea.
  • Their ribosomes are of the 70S type (smaller than the 80S ribosomes in eukaryotes).
  • The cell wall in most prokaryotes contains peptidoglycan (especially in bacteria).
  • Some prokaryotes have plasmids, which are small circular DNA molecules used in biotechnology.
  • Flagella, when present, are simpler in structure than in eukaryotic cells and aid in motility.

question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a plant cell?
option_4: Cell wall is present
solution:
• One of the most distinctive characteristics of a plant cell is the presence of a cell wall.
  • This cell wall surrounds the plasma membrane and is primarily made of cellulose, providing the cell with rigidity, fixed shape, and protection.
  • It also helps the plant cell maintain turgor pressure, which supports the structure of non-woody parts of the plant.

Additional Information:

  • Cell walls are present in plants, fungi, algae, and some bacteria, but not in animal cells.
  • The plant cell wall consists of three layers: the middle lamella, primary wall, and secondary wall.
  • Middle lamella contains pectin, which binds adjacent cells together.

question: Which among the following statements is incorrect?
option_1: Cell walls are present in animals
option_2: Cell membrane is also called the plasma membrane
option_3: Chromosomes are composed of DNA and Protein
option_4: Mitochondria are known as the powerhouse of the cell
solution:
• Option (a) is incorrect because animal cells do not have cell walls.
  • Cell walls are found in plants, fungi, algae, and some bacteria, but they are absent in animals.
  • The rest of the statements are correct:
    • (b) The cell membrane is indeed also called the plasma membrane.
    • (c) Chromosomes are made of DNA and histone proteins.
    • (d) Mitochondria generate ATP and are rightly called the powerhouse of the cell.

Additional Information:

  • Animal cells have only a plasma membrane, which is flexible and allows cell movement and shape change.
  • The absence of a rigid cell wall gives animal cells more flexibility compared to plant cells.
  • Robert Hooke discovered cell walls in cork, but he observed dead plant cells, not animal ones.

question: Cytology is the study of ________ .
solution:
• Cytology is the branch of biology that deals with the study of cells — their structure, function, composition, and life processes.
  • The word comes from the Greek:
    • “kytos” meaning cell, and
    • “logos” meaning study.
  • Cytology includes the examination of cell organelles, cell division, and cell interactions, typically under a microscope.

Additional Information:

  • The father of cytology is Robert Hooke, who first observed dead cells in cork in 1665.
  • Modern cytology uses tools like electron microscopy and cell staining techniques to observe detailed structures.
  • Cytology has applications in medical diagnosis, especially in cancer screening (e.g. Pap smear test).

question: Plant cell have a big central ______ unlike a number of small _____ in animal cells.
option_2: Cell wall, cell walls
option_4: Cell membrane, cell membranes
solution:
• Plant cells typically have a large central vacuole that can occupy up to 90% of the cell volume.
  • This central vacuole helps in storage of water, waste, and nutrients, and also maintains turgor pressure, which supports the plant structure.
  • In contrast, animal cells may have multiple small vacuoles instead of a single large one.
  • Hence, the correct completion is:

    "Plant cells have a big central vacuole unlike a number of small vacuoles in animal cells."

Additional Information:

  • The central vacuole in plant cells is surrounded by a membrane called the tonoplast.
  • Vacuoles also help in detoxification and maintaining pH balance in cells.
  • In unicellular organisms, vacuoles can function in excretion and digestion as well.

question: Which among the following is the structural and fundamental unit of life?
solution:
• The cell is considered the structural and fundamental unit of life because all living organisms are composed of cells.
  • It is the smallest unit that can carry out all the basic life processes like metabolism, growth, reproduction, and response to stimuli.
  • This concept is part of the Cell Theory, proposed by Schleiden and Schwann, which states that:
    • All living organisms are made up of one or more cells.
    • The cell is the basic unit of life.
    • All cells arise from pre-existing cells (added later by Virchow).

Additional Information:

  • Tissues are groups of similar cells performing a common function.
  • Enzymes are biological catalysts, not structural units.
  • Hormones are chemical messengers, not structural units of life.

question: Which of the following is a complex permanent plant tissue?
solution:
• Xylem is a complex permanent plant tissue, responsible for conducting water and minerals from roots to other parts of the plant.
  • It is called complex because it consists of different types of cells, such as:
    • Tracheids
    • Vessels
    • Xylem parenchyma
    • Xylem fibres
  • These cells work together to provide mechanical support and water conduction.

Additional Information:

  • Lateral and apical meristems are meristematic tissues (not permanent) involved in plant growth.
  • Collenchyma is a simple permanent tissue that provides flexibility and mechanical support.
  • Another complex permanent tissue in plants is phloem, which transports food.

question: Which cell organelles help in intercellular digestion and are known as the “Suicidal bags” of the cell?
solution:
• Lysosomes are membrane-bound cell organelles that contain digestive enzymes.
  • They help in intercellular digestion by breaking down worn-out cell parts, invading pathogens, or even the entire cell in case of damage.
  • Because they can digest the cell itself when necessary, they are famously known as the "suicidal bags" of the cell.
  • Lysosomes are formed by the Golgi apparatus and are mostly found in animal cells.

Additional Information:

  • Lysosomes contain powerful hydrolytic enzymes like proteases, lipases, and nucleases.
  • Malfunction of lysosomes can lead to lysosomal storage diseases (e.g., Tay-Sachs disease).
  • Plant cells rarely have lysosomes; instead, vacuoles perform similar digestive roles.
